data.enText: showing that you really mean the opposite of what you are saying; expressing

data.chText: （因出乎意料而）奇怪的，好笑的
data.enText: strange or amusing because it is very different from what you expect

data.chText: 令人啼笑皆非的是她成了教师——她过去一向厌恶上学。
data.enText: It's ironic that she became a teacher─she used to hate school.

data.chText: 具有讽刺意味的是，那本书她觉得最糟糕，却比她的其他任何一本书卖得都好。
data.enText: Ironically, the book she felt was her worst sold more copies than any of her others.

means: (因出乎意料而)奇怪的，好笑的

tr: characterized by often poignant difference or incongruity between what is expected and what actually is
example: madness, an ironic fate for such a clear thinker
it was ironical that the well-planned scheme failed so completely
an ironic remark often conveys an intended meaning obliquely

value.def: When you make an ironic remark, you say something that you do not mean, as a joke.

example.ex: At the most solemn moments he will flash a mocking smile or make an ironic remark...
example.tran: 在最庄严的时刻他脸上会闪现嘲弄的微笑或说一句讽刺挖苦的话。

example.ex: People used to call me Mr Popularity at high school, but they were being ironic.
example.tran: 人们中学时常把我称作“万人迷先生”,但他们是在挖苦我。

value.def: If you say that it is ironic that something should happen, you mean that it is odd or amusing because it involves a contrast.

example.ex: Does he not find it ironic that the sort of people his movie celebrates hardly ever watch this kind of movie?
example.tran: 他电影里颂扬的那些人几乎从不看这种电影,难道他不觉得这是种讽刺吗？

value.tran: 具有讽刺意味的;令人啼笑皆非的
